head.title: A Grill Where Colors and Music Ring Out

hedline.hl1: A Grill Where Colors and Music Ring Out

abstract.p: M H Reed reviews Sammy's Grill and Bar in Somers, NY; photos (M)

block.p: DINERS inclined to think of Sammy's Grill and Bar as a predictable hamburger and ribs place might think again.

Certainly the witty décor should rattle expectations; the new owners may well have put all their decorating capital into paint: the captain's chairs vibrate with bold hues, as do the tables, gleaming as though lacquered. Pendant wagon-wheel chandeliers, their hurricane shades awash with color, cast their stained-glass light on figures painted on the walls and on the stuffed, life-size figures perched on the high rafters.
DINERS inclined to think of Sammy's Grill and Bar as a predictable hamburger and ribs place might think again.

Certainly the witty décor should rattle expectations; the new owners may well have put all their decorating capital into paint: the captain's chairs vibrate with bold hues, as do the tables, gleaming as though lacquered. Pendant wagon-wheel chandeliers, their hurricane shades awash with color, cast their stained-glass light on figures painted on the walls and on the stuffed, life-size figures perched on the high rafters.

The draw at Sammy's, for many, might be the late-night music, the range of generous offerings -- dishes here will suit all ages -- and the view, particularly in this warm season. Small patio and picture windows at the back of the restaurant look out onto a pretty pond and its geese. After dark, on Friday and Saturday nights, there's live music in the lounge.

Some appetizers like the heap of fresh-tasting nachos with salsa, guacamole and Cheddar cheese could easily be consumed at the bar. Fat, inventive quesadillas were large enough to serve as entrees. A soft spinach tortilla wrapped chunks of lobster, avocado and Manchego cheese in a harmonious combination of flavors and textures. Quesadilla with chicken proved almost as good.

Crab cakes and tempura shrimp, both resting on greens, were fine though standard issue, as was Sammy's chili with the usual shreds of beef, Cheddar cheese, onions and sour cream. A huge portobello cap, crusted in an armor of crushed nuts that made the dish chokingly dry, was a total miss.

Sammy's dishes echo both American-regional and foreign kitchens. Items like quesadillas, chili, coconut shrimp, wasabi salmon, southern fried chicken and Asian short ribs, to name a few, fill out the menu. A tasty Thai stir fry of firm shrimp, shredded vegetables and fragrant peanut sauce was dished over icy cold noodles, a pity, since the dish was otherwise delightful. Noodles, as a bed for juicy seared salmon with mild wasabi, came appropriately hot in this fine dish.

An order of barbecue ribs brought a full rack, so large it hung over the platter and so tender that the hickory-smoked meat almost fell off the bone. Coconut-crusted shrimp with couscous and fruity salsa were better than overly grilled shrimp with risotto.

The long list of sandwiches was well worth consideration. A mere lick of horseradish added kick to lobster salad heaped into a tender roasted roll. A soft bun was filled with pulled barbecue pork with a few shavings of onion. But high hopes for the featured Sammy's Big Daddy Burger were dashed: ordered medium rare, the meat arrived overcooked, tough and dry.
A very short list of standard wines was fairly priced. The selection of beers was more interesting. Most were bottled from microbrewers like Saranac and Blackened Voodoo.

Desserts were acceptable without being inspirational. Key lime pie with a lovely buttery crust needed more of the lime's tart, citric zing. But rich brownie ran with good, moderately sweet chocolate sauce. Sorbets and ice cream will please the cautious.
Sammy's Grill and Bar 289 Route 100, Somers. (914)276-0600

ATMOSPHERE -- Long, narrow dining room and separate bar and lounge awash with bold colors -- purple, acid green, orange -- in an unpretentious old roadhouse. High ceilings, bare floors and tabletops amplify noise. Small back patio overlooks a pretty pond. Good service. Live music begins at 10 on most Friday and Saturday nights. RECOMMENDED DISHES -- Lobster and avocado quesadilla, chicken quesadilla, nachos, Thai shrimp lo mein, barbecue ribs, wasabi salmon, coconut shrimp, brownie. The menu is still being fine-tuned; some dishes may no longer be available. PRICES -- Lunch and dinner, $9 to $27, with some appetizers generous enough to serve as entrees. Brunch, $7 to $16. CREDIT CARDS -- Major cards accepted. HOURS -- Sundays through Thursdays, 11:30 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Fridays, 11:30 a.m. to 11 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 11 p.m., bar is open late. Brunch, Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. RESERVATIONS -- Advisable for large parties or for specific tables. WHEELCHAIR ACCESS -- Street level. THE RATINGS -- Excellent. Very good. Good. Satisfactory. Poor.
Ratings reflect the reviewer's reaction primarily to food, with ambience and service taken into consideration. Menu listings and prices are subject to change.
